item.title: Senators who suffered strokes urge public to prioritize wellness
item.description: Senators Chris Van Hollen and Ben Ray Luj√°n reflect on their experiences recovering from strokes.

item.title: Did I get the polio vaccine? How to know if you're protected against the virus
item.description: A case of polio was identified in Rockland County, New York, and now the virus has been detected in New York City's wastewater.

item.title: Polio detected in New York City wastewater
item.description: Polio has been detected in New York City's wastewater, suggesting further circulation of the virus. The city's health department is urging pediatricians to immediately identify and schedule appointments for children who are behind on their polio immunizations. Elaine Quijano shares more details.

item.title: Idaho Supreme Court rules that abortion restrictions can take effect
item.description: One of the laws slated to take effect allows potential relatives of an embryo or fetus to sue abortion providers for up to $20,000 within four years of an abortion.

item.title: Polio detected in NYC's sewage, suggesting virus circulating
item.description: Last month, the New York Health Department reported the nation's first case of polio in almost a decade, in Rockland County, north of New York City.

item.title: Pig skin protein gives sight back to 14 blind people
item.description: The bioengineered corneas could provide a new and less invasive solution for the millions around the world in need of cornea transplants.

item.title: Oatly, Grumpy, Organic Valley beverage recall expands
item.description: Lyons Magnus is recalling more than 80 types of drinks over possible contamination with bacteria that causes botulism.

item.title: Dr. Ashish Jha on what the Biden administration is doing about monkeypox
item.description: Monkeypox has been declared a public health emergency. Dr. Ashish Jha details what the Biden Administration plans to do to contain the outbreak.

item.title: Senate passes climate, tax and health care package
item.description: After long negotiations and more than 24 hours of voting, the Senate passed a spending bill aimed at tackling climate change, reducing drug costs and addressing inflation on Sunday along strict party lines. Congressional correspondent Nikole Killion details path to the final vote.

item.title: CDC draft report points to possible easing of COVID restrictions in schools
item.description: CBS News has obtained a draft report that indicates COVID restrictions in the classroom having to do with testing and social distancing could soon be eased. While not final, the recommendations could also lift quarantine recommendations for those exposed to the virus, whether they are vaccinated or not. Nancy Chen reports.

item.title: Lawmakers asking Department of Defense to do more about civilians' medical bills
item.description: Only on "CBS Mornings," members of Congress are calling on the Department of Defense to do more to help civilians who have gotten huge medical bills for emergency treatment at U.S. military facilities. A non-partisan government report says that even though many of those bills could be waived or reduced, the DOD almost never does. Anna Werner reports.

item.title: Doctors share concerns over abortion laws, dangers
item.description: Four doctors share their concerns about why abortion restrictions are causing confusion and putting patients' lives at risk.

item.title: British veteran builds castle in Welsh Valley to help with PTSD
item.description: A British veteran struggling with PTSD built a castle in the Welsh Valley to help with his mental health. It's now become a sanctuary for other veterans and military widows. CBS News foreign correspondent Roxana Saberi has more.

item.title: Immunotherapy trial for rectal cancer offers hope for future
item.description: A small immunotherapy trial for a certain type of rectal cancer reports a 100% success rate. Dr. Jon LaPook explains how it's designed to work, and how it could be used as a model to treat other cancers.

item.title: New study finds intermittent fasting could help weight loss, hypertension and mood
item.description: A new study published in the JAMA Internal Medicine found eating only between the hours of 7 a.m. and 3 p.m. could help people lose weight and treat hypertension. Good Housekeeping's deputy nutrition director and registered dietician Stefani Sassos joins "CBS Mornings" to discuss the study's findings and limitations.

item.title: CDC relaxes COVID-19 guidelines
item.description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention updated its COVID-19 guidance to loosen a number of its recommendations. CBS News' chief medical correspondent Dr. Jon LaPook has the details.

item.title: CDC updates its COVID-19 guidelines in sweeping overhaul
item.description: The agency says the new revisions acknowledge "the pandemic is not over" but should not disrupt daily life as much as it used to.

item.title: As U.S. hits 10,000 monkeypox cases, CDC still aims for "containment"
item.description: Every state but one has reported at least one infection in the outbreak, which now ranks as the largest in the world.

item.title: Debt lawsuits against relatives and friends of nursing home residents
item.description: Along with our partners Kaiser Health News and NPR, CBS News has found that what starts out as a good deed can turn into a legal nightmare in some cases.

item.title: Nursing homes are suing friends and family to collect on patients' bills
item.description: In partnership with Kaiser Health News and NPR, CBS News takes a look at an alarming trend of nursing homes filing lawsuits against not only residents, but their friends and family to collect unpaid bills. Often the person being sued has no financial ties to the actual resident or legal responsibility for their debt. Anna Werner has more

item.title: Monkeypox: What we know about the outbreak, vaccinations and treatments
item.description: The CDC expects cases will continue to climb through at least August.

item.title: New animal-derived Langya virus infects 35 in Eastern China
item.description: Though the virus has not yet caused any fatalities, it comes from the same family as other deadly viruses.

item.title: Experimental treatment changes lives for cancer patients in small trial
item.description: An experimental trial for rectal cancer had a 100% resolution rate among its 18 patients.

item.title: What you need to know about Medicare Part A's depletion date
item.description: Medicare's Hospital Insurance trust fund will run out of money in 2028, trustees say.

item.title: Polio vaccine to be offered to London kids after more virus found
item.description: Britain's Health Security Agency said it had detected polio viruses derived from the oral polio vaccine in sewage water from eight boroughs of London.

item.title: U.S. moves to stretch out monkeypox vaccine supply
item.description: The Food and Drug Administration has greenlit the Biden administration's plan to stretch out its limited supply of monkeypox vaccine by allowing shots that use only one-fifth of the usual dose.

item.title: U.S. will stretch monkeypox vaccine supply with smaller doses
item.description: Health officials are citing research suggesting that the reduced amount is about as effective.

item.title: What is vasculitis? Ashton Kutcher says he battled rare disease
item.description: "I had this weird, super rare form of vasculitis, that like knocked out my vision, it knocked out my hearing, it knocked out like all my equilibrium," Kutcher said.

item.title: What is having monkeypox like? Survivor opens up on illness and recovery
item.description: Todd called for more informed health care providers and faster responses from government officials.

item.title: How to stay cool and safe during a heat wave, according to experts
item.description: Experts shared their major do's and don'ts for keeping cool during high temperatures ‚Äî with and without air conditioning ‚Äî with CBS News.
